messages.content:
You are a professional academic reference prediction expert. Your task is to predict the most likely references for a given academic paper based on its title, abstract, and retrieved relevant papers.

RETRIEVER INTERFACE:
- Input: paper title + abstract
- Output: {top_r} retrieved papers with title and abstract
- Format: List of dictionaries with 'title' and 'abstract' fields

REQUIREMENTS:
1. Analyze the paper's title and abstract to understand its research area and focus
2. Consider the retrieved papers as potential references (when available)
3. Generate a list of predicted reference titles that would be most relevant and likely to be cited
4. Provide reasoning for each prediction to prevent hallucination
5. Output format: JSON object with "titles" array and "reasoning" string
6. Generate exactly 48 most relevant reference titles (this should be at least 40 to cover all evaluation metrics)
7. Ensure titles are realistic and appropriate for the research area
8. Consider citation patterns in the field
9. CRITICAL: Each title must be unique - never repeat the same title multiple times

EXAMPLE:
Input:
Title: "Question Type Classification Methods Comparison"
Abstract: "The paper presents a comparative study of state-of-the-art approaches for question classification task: Logistic Regression, Convolutional Neural Networks (CNN), Long Short-Term Memory Network (LSTM) and Quasi-Recurrent Neural Networks (QRNN). All models use pre-trained GLoVe word embeddings and trained on human-labeled data. The best accuracy is achieved using CNN model with five convolutional layers and various kernel sizes stacked in parallel, followed by one fully connected layer. The model reached 90.7% accuracy on TREC 10 test set."

Retrieved papers ({top_r}):
1. Title: Convolutional Neural Networks for Sentence Classification
   Abstract: We report on a series of experiments with convolutional neural networks trained on top of pre-trained word vectors for sentence-level classification tasks.

2. Title: Glove: Global vectors for word representation
   Abstract: We present a new global log-bilinear regression model that combines the advantages of the two major model families in the literature.

Output:
{
  "titles": [
    "Convolutional Neural Networks for Sentence Classification",
    "Glove: Global vectors for word representation",
    "Quasi-Recurrent Neural Networks",
    "A Comparative Study of Neural Network Models for Sentence Classification",
    "Deep lstm based feature mapping for query classification"
  ],
  "reasoning": "Based on the paper's focus on question classification using neural networks, I predict these references because: 1) CNN paper is directly relevant to the convolutional approach used; 2) GloVe embeddings are mentioned as pre-trained features; 3) QRNN is one of the compared methods; 4) Comparative study papers are common in this field; 5) LSTM-based query classification is closely related to question classification. Additional references cover related neural network architectures, NLP applications, deep learning methodologies, optimization techniques, and advanced neural network methods that would be relevant for this research area."
}

Return JSON object only.

Paper Title: The Space Complexity of Sum Labelling

Paper Abstract: Abstract A graph is called a sum graph if its vertices can be labelled by distinct positive integers such that there is an edge between two vertices if and only if the sum of their labels is the label of another vertex of the graph. Most papers on sum graphs consider combinatorial questions like the minimum number of isolated vertices that need to be added to a given graph to make it a sum graph. In this paper, we initiate the study of sum graphs from the viewpoint of computational complexity. Notice that every n𝑛n-vertex sum graph can be represented by a sorted list of n𝑛n positive integers where edge queries can be answered in 𝒪​(log⁡n)𝒪𝑛\mathscr{O}(\log n) time. Therefore, limiting the size of the vertex labels upper-bounds the space complexity of storing the graph in the database. We show that every n𝑛n-vertex, m𝑚m-edge, d𝑑d-degenerate graph can be made a sum graph by adding at most m𝑚m isolated vertices to it, such that the size of each vertex label is at most 𝒪​(n2​d)𝒪superscript𝑛2𝑑\mathscr{O}(n^{2}d). This enables us to store the graph using 𝒪​(m​log⁡n)𝒪𝑚𝑛\mathscr{O}(m\log n) bits of memory. For sparse graphs (graphs with 𝒪​(n)𝒪𝑛\mathscr{O}(n) edges), this matches the trivial lower bound of Ω​(n​log⁡n)Ω𝑛𝑛\Omega(n\log n). As planar graphs and forests have constant degeneracy, our result implies an upper bound of 𝒪​(n2)𝒪superscript𝑛2\mathscr{O}(n^{2}) on their label size. The previously best known upper bound on the label size of general graphs with the minimum number of isolated vertices was 𝒪​(4n)𝒪superscript4𝑛\mathscr{O}(4^{n}), due to Kratochvíl, Miller & Nguyen (2001). Furthermore, their proof was existential, whereas our labelling can be constructed in polynomial time.

{retrieved_text}

Generate exactly 48 most likely reference titles for this paper. Focus on papers that are directly related to the research topic, provide foundational background, present similar methodologies, or address related problems.

CRITICAL: Each title must appear exactly once. Do not repeat any title.

IMPORTANT: You must respond with ONLY valid JSON in this exact format:
{
    "titles": [
        "Reference Title 1",
        "Reference Title 2",
        "Reference Title 3",
        "Reference Title 4",
        "Reference Title 48"
    ],
    "reasoning": "Explain why you chose these specific references based on the paper's title, abstract, and retrieved papers. This helps prevent hallucination and ensures relevance."
}

Do not include any text before or after the JSON. Do not include authors, venues, or years - only the paper titles. The reasoning field is required to explain your prediction logic.

{
    "titles": [
        "Survey of graph database models",
        "A comparison of current graph database models",
        "Planar graphs, via well-orderly maps and trees",
        "Shorter labeling schemes for planar graphs",
        "Product graphs are sum graphs",
        "Adjacency labelling for planar graphs (and beyond)",
        "Survey of graph database performance on the HPC scalable graph analysis benchmark",
        "The early history of the factorial function",
        "Universal codeword sets and representations of the integers",
        "Sum graphs from trees",
        "The space complexity of sum labelling",
        "A sum labelling for the generalised friendship graph",
        "A dynamic survey of graph labeling, version 23",
        "Combinatorial Algorithms: 31st International Workshop, IWOCA 2020, Bordeaux, France, June 8-10, 2020, Proceedings, volume 12126",
        "Shorter implicit representation for planar graphs and bounded treewidth graphs",
        "Bounds on the number of isolated vertices in sum graphs",
        "Sum graphs and difference graphs",
        "Sum graphs over all the integers",
        "A family of sparse graphs of large sum number",
        "An empirical comparison of graph databases",
        "Graph databases: A survey",
        "Minimal sum labeling of graphs",
        "Sum graph labels – an upper bound and related problems",
        "Implicit representation of graphs",
        "Constructing labeling schemes through universal matrices",
        "Short encodings of planar graphs and maps",
        "Benchmark graphs for testing community detection algorithms",
        "k𝑘k-degenerate graphs",
        "Exclusive sum labeling of graphs",
        "Succinct representation of balanced parentheses and static trees",
        "Characterisation of graphs with exclusive sum labelling",
        "The sum number of the cocktail party graph",
        "On the number of isolates in graph labeling",
        "Proximity-preserving labeling schemes",
        "New formula for the sum number for the complete bipartite graphs",
        "Exclusive sum labeling of graphs: A survey",
        "Planar graphs and poset dimension",
        "Embedding planar graphs on the grid",
        "The On-Line Encyclopedia of Integer Sequences, OEIS Foundation Inc. (2021)",
        "Mod sum graph labelling of Hm,nsubscript𝐻𝑚𝑛H_{m,n} and Knsubscript𝐾𝑛K_{n}",
        "On the sum number of wheels",
        "Connected graphs which are not mod sum graphs",
        "Sum graphs of small sum number",
        "Sum graph based access structure in a secret sharing scheme",
        "Some results on the spum and the integral spum of graphs",
        "Summable Graph Labellings and Their Applications",
        "Delta-optimum exclusive sum labeling of certain graphs with radius one",
        "The sum number and integral sum number of complete bipartite graphs"
    ],
    "reasoning": "Selected these 48 references because they represent foundational work and recent advances in The Space Complexity of Sum Labelling, providing essential background knowledge and methodological foundations relevant to this research."
}
